Award.AwardTitle: University of Wisconsin-Stout REU Site in Mathematics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Department of Mathematics, Statistics and Computer Science at the University of Wisconsin-Stout will host an REU in mathematics where 8 students will attend an 8 week summer research program during each of the summers of 2012--2014. The research theme for the projects is the use of computational tools to address geometric questions in algebra and analysis. The program will involve students in research that addresses open questions in algebraic geometry, complex analysis and geometric group theory. Participants will be organized into two groups consisting of four students and two faculty mentors each, with a resident computer science faculty member providing theoretical and practical computer science support to both groups. The projects have been designed to allow students a strong chance to achieve results and partial results that are important to the current research of their faculty mentors.

Broader objectives of this REU are, (1) to increase the participation in mathematics research by first-generation college students, (2) to motivate these students to pursue graduate education, (3) to prepare participants to succeed in graduate school. Many universities throughout the upper Midwest region where UW-Stout is located have large percentages of first-generation students, and at these schools we will specifically recruit qualified first-generation students who may not otherwise consider attending graduate school or an REU. We will prepare and motivate participants for graduate school through professional development seminars in skills necessary for success in graduate school as well as visits to industry and guest lectures that will expose the participants to a broad range of possible research careers. Additionally, research projects have been selected that introduce students to subjects and tools that they will encounter in graduate school but that they may not see in their undergraduate work. After the program ends, communication will be maintained with participants for the purposes of writing up and publishing results obtained, presenting results at national and regional conferences and for serving as resource mentors for the participants as they begin the next phases of their academic and professional careers.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Wisconsin-Stout (UW-Stout) Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site in Mathematics run in summers of 2012, 2013, and 2014 on UW-Stout campus, which is located in Menomonie, WI.  For each summer, 8 students were recruited from a nationwide search with the use of www.mathprograms.org website. 

Each REU ran for eight weeks from early June until early August. Each participant received funds for travel to and from UW-Stout, and a stipend for their work. Each participant was provided with free campus housing for the duration of the REU.

Each summer the 8 participants were organized into 4 research groups, each comprised of 2 REU participants and a faculty mentor.

Throughout the duration of the project REU students were mentored by 6 faculty from University of Wisconsin - Stout (which includes the two principal investigators) and 1 faculty from University of Wisconsin - Eau Claire. Another UW-Stout faculty was serving the entire REU team as a resource in computer science, and another senior UW-Stout faculty served as a resource to the team of mentors.

The main research activity throughout the REU was for the students to work collaboratively with their group mentor and research partners on an open problem in the mentor's research area. Throughout the duration of the project the participants were engaged in explorations and research in geometric group theory, geometry of complex analytic sets, algebraic geometry, invariant theory, computational methods for partial differential equations, finite group theory, and pseudoknots.

Each REU began with intensive introduction to the focus area of the research group; the participants were made aware of the potential research problems. By the start of the second week the participants chose a problem that they wanted to work on. For the last sex weeks of the REU, participants worked collaboratively with their group mentor and research partners on the chosen problem. Each week the research groups made a presentation on their progress.

After the conclusion of the REU, twenty-three of the twenty-four participants presented their research at national conferences that included Joint Mathematical Meetings, MAA MathFest, National Conference on Undergraduate Research, and SIAM Conference on Computational Science and Engineering. Four papers resulting from REU were published in peer reviewed journals.

After the REU, fifteen of the twenty-four participants enrolled in graduate programs. Of the fifteen participants who were first-generation students (their parents did not hold a four-year degree), eleven enrolled in graduate programs.
